title: 040 Strict Adherence to the IEEE Specification
By default, floating point operations on
float
c
and
double
c
do not
i
strictly adhere to the rules of the IEEE 754 specification. An expression is allowed to use implementation-specific extensions to the range of these values; essentially allowing them to be
more
i
accurate than required.

strictly adhere to the rules of the IEEE 754 specification. An expression is allowed to use implementation-specific extensions to the range of these values; essentially allowing them to be

title: strictfp
c
disables this behavior. It is applied to a class, interface, or method, and applies to everything contained in it, such as classes, interfaces, methods, constructors, variable initializers, etc. With
strictfp
c
, the intermediate values of a floating-point expression
must
i
be within the float value set or the double value set. This causes the results of such expressions to be exactly those that the IEEE 754 specification predicts.

title: All constant expressions are implicitly strict, even if they aren’t inside a
strictfp
c
scope.

title: Therefore,
strictfp
c
has the net effect of sometimes making certain corner case computations
less
i
accurate, and can also make floating point operations
slower
i

(as the CPU is now doing more work to ensure any native extra precision does not affect the result). However, it also causes the results to be exactly the same on all platforms. It is therefore useful in things like scientific programs, where reproducibility is more important than speed.
